The Second Decentralized Health Services Project (DHS2) will support 
comprehensive  reform  and  capacity-building  efforts  of  the  Ministry  of 
Health (MOH) and the National Family Coordinating Board (BKKBN) in 
the context of decentralization. Focusing on the needs of the poor, the 
DHS2  will  increase  the  quality  and  effectiveness  of  health  and  family 
planning  services  in  the  project  area  by  improving  clinical  and 
managerial  skills  of  health  personnel,  upgrading  health  facilities  and 
equipment,  and  involving  civil  society  in  planning  and  monitoring  of 
service provision. 
 
Decentralization  offers  new  opportunities  to  strengthen  health  and 
family planning services in the regions through locally adapted reforms 
giving  health  services  providers  more  appropriate  incentives,  skills, 
supervision,  material  support,  and  discretionary  authority  needed  to 
offer  high  quality  services,  and  providing  clients  with  information, 
financial  means,  and  bargaining  power  required  to  elicit  appropriate 
responses.  A  mix  of  human,  physical,  and  financial  resources  are 
needed  to  help  the  regions  and  the  central  Government  plan, 
implement,  manage,  monitor,  and  evaluate  a  range  of  programs  and 
activities.  Low  quality  of  public  health  services  in  Indonesia  affects 
mainly  the  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  and  is  linked  to  a  range  of 
shortcomings in the health sector, which indicate chronic underfunding. 
The  DHS2  will  address  these  deficits  while  focusing  on  the  health 
needs  of  the  poor.  A  better  health  status  will  give  the  poor  and  the 
community  at  large  greater  opportunity  to  fully  participate  in  the 
economic development of their specific region and the country.  
 
The DHS2 will help improve the health status of people in 8 provinces 
of  Indonesia,  particularly  concentrating  on  improving  health  services 
geared  to  women,  children,  and  infants.    The  DHS2  will  increase  the 
clinical  and  managerial  capacity  of  health  personnel  at  all  levels  of 
government, strengthen regulatory and quality assurance functions, and 
result in improved local health and family planning services. 
 
The total project cost is $143.0 million equivalent, of which $73.2 million 
(51%) is the foreign exchange cost and $69.8 million equivalent (49%) 
represents the local currency costs.

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
From  1970  to  2001,  life  expectancy  at  birth  increased  from  46  to  64  years  of  age  for 
males  and  to  68  years  of  age  for  females,  reflecting  the  decline  in  the  infant  and  under-5 
mortality  rates.  Infant  mortality  declined  from  145  to  33  infant  deaths  and  under-5  mortality 
declined  from  172  to  45  per  thousand  live  births.  Easier  access  to  health  services  combined 
with economic growth and better education contributed to improving the health status. However, 
Indonesia’s  health  status  indicators  remain  low2  and  achievements  have  been  uneven  across 
provinces,  between  urban  and  rural  areas,  and  between  rich  and  poor  segments  of  the 
population. With 25% of all under-5-year-old children underweight and 50% of pregnant women 
suffering  from  iron  deficiency  anemia,  malnutrition  remains  a  public  health  issue.  Maternal 
mortality, estimated at 380 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, is unacceptably high. While 
cardiovascular and chronic diseases have become the main causes of mortality, infectious and 
parasitic diseases, which particularly affect the poor, dominate morbidity. Tuberculosis, malaria, 
respiratory  infections,  and  diarrhea  remain  major  public  health  issues.  This  combination  of 
chronic,  life-style,  and  infectious  diseases  creates  a  double  burden  of  diseases  for  the  health 
system  of  the  country.  A  detailed  description  of  the  health  sector  and  its  performance  in  the 
project area is in Appendix 2. 
 
3. 
Over  the  last  3  decades,  Indonesia  has  given  priority  to  improving  physical  access  to 
primary  health  care  (PHC)  services.  The  average  distance  to  a  health  facility  in  2002  was  5 
kilometers  in  rural  areas  and  1.5  kilometers  in  urban  areas,  but  chronic  underfunding  and 
inefficient  targeting  has  prevented  better  results.  Total  national  expenditures  for  health  have 
been low by international standards. In 1995, only 1.6% of gross domestic product was spent on 
health.  The  proportion  increased  to  2.7%  in  2000,  but  the  Government’s  share  of  health 
expenditure, excluding external aid, fell from 46.0% in 1995 to 23.7%. The percentage of central 
Government  expenditure  allocated  to  the  health  sector  is  only  2%,  compared  with  5%  in  the 
Philippines  and  8%  in  Thailand.  Health  expenditure  per  capita  ($19)  is  below  the  average  of 
low-income  countries  ($21),  the  Philippines  ($33),  and  Thailand  ($71).  Chronic  underfunding 
has  affected  maintenance  of  facilities;  procurement  of  medical  equipment,  drugs,  and  other 
supplies; and the quality of training for health workers, before and after graduation. A low 30% 
utilization rate of public health services suggests low client satisfaction.  
 
4.

an  obstacle  to  the  use  of  health  services.  The  World  Bank  found  that  the  richest  20%  of  the

5. 
The Government has developed a successful family planning program advocating birth 
spacing,  small  families,  and  family  welfare.4  Spearheaded  by  the  National  Family  Planning

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

6. 
Since January 2001, regional governments are responsible for financing and delivery of 
health  services  in  the  context  of  regional  autonomy  and  decentralization.  With  second-tier 
regional  governments  now  being  the  deciding  authority  regarding  health  policies  and  budget 
allocations for their regions, the national and provincial authorities cannot determine the health 
agenda of districts and cities anymore. This raises issues of coordination and regulation as well 
as  of  quality  assurance.  The  announcement  of  obligatory  functions  and  minimum  service 
standards has given the national Government an important tool to ensure quality and regulation 
in the sector. This will allow the Ministry of Health (MOH) to specifically address shortcomings of 
regional  health  services  in  relation  to  defined  service  standards.  Project-related  annual  health 
sector  plans  of  regional  governments  as  practiced  by  the  ongoing  Decentralized  Health 
Services  (DHS1)  Project  provide  another  opportunity  to  enforce  quality  and  compliance  with 
defined  standards  because  plans  have  to  be  consistent  with  the  central  Government's  norms 
and quality requirements. 
 
Decentralization  can  increase  accountability  of  health  service  providers  and  regional 
7. 
authorities and offer greater opportunity for the community to influence resource allocation and 
service quality. Since the allocation of resources is now decided by elected regional authorities 
and  no  longer  by  technocrats  in  the  central  Government,  allocation criteria  and  priorities  have 
become  part  of  the  political  debate.  Without  appropriate  capacity  building  and  advocacy, 
regional  governments  may  not  become  aware  of  the  benefits  of  investing  in  health  and  family 
planning, and health needs of poor and vulnerable groups may not become a political priority. 
Although quality PHC services, maternal and child health, and nutrition programs are universally 
recognized to be highly cost-effective programs that benefit the poor, regional governments may 
prefer  to  invest  in  high  profile  hospitals  that  would  undermine  sector  cost-effectiveness. 
Decentralization requires a new approach and a new role from MOH different from the previous 
focus on top-down planning and budgeting.  
 
8. 
Equally, new skills and knowledge are required at the regional levels. In a decentralized 
environment,  regional  health  staff  are  in  charge  of  needs  identification,  planning,  budgeting, 
monitoring,  and  evaluation.  Essential  drugs  must  be  purchased  and  health  staff  must  be 
properly  qualified  to  prescribe  them  in  an  appropriate  manner.  Even  with  qualified  health 
personnel,  poor  health  facilities  and  insufficient  medical  equipment  prevent  the  provision  of 
quality services. Also, financing of the health services in terms of cost sharing between different

The quantity and qualification of primary health workers is a major issue. Indonesia has 
9. 
on average one doctor per 6,000–7,000 people, but the situation is worse in rural areas where 
remote localities remain underserved with less than one doctor per health center. Young doctors 
and  midwives  are  required  to  provide  PHC  services  under  a  3-year  compulsory  contract.  The 
doctors work in district hospitals and health centers and midwives are posted in health centers 
and  in  small  village-based  health  facilities.  Incentives,  benefits,  and  opportunities  vary  and 
depend largely on the individual regional government. Specialized doctors tend to move toward 
bigger  urban  centers,  which  offer  better  professional  opportunities  and  monetary  incentives. 
This creates a major problem for the recruitment and retention of qualified health personnel in 
districts, cities, and provinces that cannot provide such incentives.  
 
10. 
Village midwives are most often the first contact of the rural population when it comes to 
health  services  and  provide  services  that  are  much  appreciated  by  the  poor.  Their  training, 
however, does not equip them to deliver quality PHC services. There is a need to offer regular 
training,  supervision,  and  necessary  equipment  and  essential  drugs.5  MOH  is  implementing  a 
new training policy to address this issue, developing hospital-based training in provinces and in 
selected districts, expecting to attract local professionals that will stay in the region.  
 
11. 
Starting  on  1  January  2004,  BKKBN  will  have  to  decentralize  its  successful  family 
planning services, and regional governments will become responsible for ensuring access to the 
family planning and reproductive health programs. BKKBN’s vision is to help Indonesian families 
become prosperous, healthy, and independent, with two children only, and to provide access to 
family  planning  services  for  the  poor.  A  particular  policy  of  BKKBN  is  to  ensure  continuous 
availability of free or subsidized contraceptives for the poor. However, this policy may be difficult 
to  maintain  because  major  donors—in  particular  the  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development—have announced their withdrawal from the population and family planning sector.  
 
12.  MOH and BKKBN are obliged by decentralization laws to adjust to new roles that include 
regulatory and standardization functions; provision of guidance and capacity building; reform of 
the health sector, including health care financing; mobilization of resources; and monitoring and 
evaluation of service quality. MOH has developed a list of essential health services that must be 
provided  by  districts  and  municipalities.6    The  delivery  of  such  services  is  in  the  hands  of 
regional  governments,  and  MOH's  and  BKKBN's  role  is  to  advocate  a  comprehensive  and 
integrated approach to health problems instead of implementing activities through line agencies.  
 
13.

In 1998, spurred by the Asian economic crisis, the Government started implementing its 
Social Safety Net Program to protect access to social services for the poor.11 It was initiated as 
an  externally-supported  emergency  program  and  is  financed  in  the  meantime  by  special 
Government  subsidies,  but  still  waits  to  be  transformed  into  a  sustainable  long-term  program. 
MOH focused its efforts on PHC services, including emergency hospitalizations. The program, 
supported  by  ADB  with  two  sector  development  programs,  offered  free  access  to  essential 
health services for the poor at health centers and district hospitals using block grant subsidies to 
these  facilities;  a  health-center-based  feeding  program  for  infants,  children,  and  pregnant 
women;  and  increased  outreach  activities  of  the  village  midwives.  As  a  result,  visits  to  health 
centers  increased  and  more  deliveries  were  attended  by  trained  health  personnel.  The  Social 
Safety  Net  Program  brought  a  significant  infusion  of  cash  resources  for  the  health  sector. 
Focusing  on  a  limited  number  of  activities  that  targeted  the  poor  and  vulnerable  groups,  this 
Program  has  protected  universal  access  to,  and  increased  utilization  of  essential  health 
services. 
 
19. 
Health  sector  reforms  are  not  always  well  understood  by  regional  governments  and 
require  guidance,  advocacy,  and  continued  dialogue  initiated  by  the  national  Government. 
Developing better coordination of public and private service provision at the regional level has 
been  advocated  by  DHS1.    It  took  2  years  of  persuasion  before  regional  governments  were 
willing  to  consider  developing  such  partnerships.  Still,  advocacy  is  considered  to  be  more 
successful than prescription by project design.  In view of weak capacities, flexibility is needed 
during project implementation to allow project beneficiaries to modify plans and priorities based 
on  their  increasing  knowledge  and  skills.  Thus,  a  mix  of  human,  physical,  and  financial 
resources  is  needed,  including  more  effective  bottom-up  planning  and  implementation 
mechanisms  that  promote  stakeholder  participation.  Above  all,  health  services  must  become 
responsive to the needs of the poor segments of society to have an impact on the health status 
of the population at large.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

54. 
Project Benefits and Beneficiaries. The DHS2 will improve health services in districts 
and cities in the 8 selected project provinces. The outcome will be a better health status of the 
concerned population at large and of poor and vulnerable groups in particular. DHS2 activities 
give  priority  to  common  health  problems  of  poor  and  vulnerable  groups,  such  as  child 
malnutrition,  child  and  infant  mortality,  and  maternal  mortality.  About  2  million  women  and  2 
million men will benefit from the DHS2, with 9%–32% of them below the poverty line. Because 
of the priority given to mother and child health care, women will benefit disproportionately from 
the DHS2. An estimated 180,000 infant girls will benefit from the DHS2 as part of 1.51 million 
under-five girls (315,000 of them considered to be poor).  
 
55. 
Social and Poverty Analysis. In general, health services and facilities at village health 
posts,  mobile  health  centers,  village  midwives,  health  centers  cater  to  the  poor.  Poor  people 
also  use  traditional  healers  and  private  health  services  providers  because  access  to  quality 
health  services  is  often  inadequate.  In  remote  rural  areas,  health  service  facilities  are  often 
beyond the reach of the poor due to transport and high opportunity costs, or health services are 
often of low quality because of the difficulty to retain qualified health personnel in remote areas. 
The poor often cannot afford private health services except from NGOs, and the relatively low 
quality  and  ineffectiveness  of  the  public  health  sector  particularly  affect  their  health  status. 
Social and poverty issues are analyzed in detail in appendixes 10 and 11. 

 
56. 
Ill  health  is the  single most  common  trigger  for  the  deterioration  of  the  quality  of  life  of 
poor and vulnerable groups. Illness reduces household savings, lowers learning ability, reduces 

   15

productivity, and leads to a diminished quality of life, thereby creating or perpetuating poverty. 
Compared with the general population, the poor and vulnerable groups are exposed to greater 
personal and environmental risks, are less well nourished, have less access to information, and 
are less able to access health care.  
 
57. 
Vulnerable  groups  include  indigenous  peoples.  The  executing  and  implementing 
agencies  will  ensure  that  project  activities  have  a  positive  impact  on  indigenous  peoples.  To 
ensure  that  indigenous  peoples  benefit  from  the  DHS2,  the  following  measures  have  been 
developed: (i) district health plans include an assessment of the needs of indigenous peoples; 
(ii) constraints on indigenous peoples’ participation in and/or benefiting from project activities will 
be addressed; (iii) community participation in the implementation of project activities will include 
indigenous  peoples  where  relevant;  and  (iv)  monitoring  mechanism  include  the  impact  of  the 
DHS2  on  indigenous  peoples.  If  civil  works  require  resettlement,  a  resettlement  plan  will  be 
prepared, in accordance with the resettlement framework (supplementary appendix B). 

 
58. 
Access to health care is a top priority for women and their families, as women tend to be 
responsible for the care of the young, the sick, and the elderly. Thus, women’s access to health 
care  extends  beyond  the  welfare  of  the  individual  to  that  of  the  family  as  a  whole.  Women  in 
rural  areas  will  benefit  from  several  project  activities,  in  particular  the  upgrading  of  PHC  and 
family  planning  services,  strengthening  of  safe  motherhood  activities,  improvement  of  training 
institutions  for  nurses  and  midwives,  and  development  of  disease  prevention  programs. 
Women's groups will help women learn about health issues and support each other in case of 
disease.  Gender  sensitive  planning  and  budgeting  will  be  promoted  at  the  district  level,  sex-
disaggregated data on the health status of the population will be collected, and participation of 
women in managerial training will be supported. The DHS2 will promote increased numbers of 
female  health  staff  by  encouraging  enrollment  of  women  in  staff  development  and  training 
activities  sponsored  by  the  DHS2  and  setting  the  target  of  a  50%  participation  rate.  Other 
specific measures addressing gender issues are presented in the gender action plan prepared 
for the DHS2 (supplementary appendix C). 
 
59. 
Environment.  The  DHS2  will  rehabilitate  and  upgrade  health  facilities  in  the  project 
area,  such  as  hospitals,  health  centers,  subhealth  centers,  and  village  health  posts.  An  initial 
environmental assessment for project activities has been completed during project preparation. 
The  necessary  measures  will  be  taken  to  minimize  environmental  impacts.  Hospital  waste 
management  will  become  part  of  the  capacity-building  program.  A  summary  is  attached  in 
Appendix 12. All civil works will be undertaken considering minimal damage to the environment. 
 
60. 
Economic  and  Financial  Analysis.  While  the  DHS2  is  expected  to  yield  several 
benefits,  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  was  calculated  using  a  conservative  estimate  of 
the benefits of improved health of the population in the project provinces through improved use 
and  quality  of  health  services  at  the  district  level.    These  conservative  estimates  yield  a 
composite economic internal rate of return of 37%, with rates ranging from 21.5% in East Nusa 
Tenggara to 50.2% in South Sumatra. A detailed economic and financial analysis is in Appendix 
13. 
 
61. 
The  DHS2  is  primarily  expected  to  reduce  the  burden  of  disease,  measured  by  the 
reduction  in  disability-adjusted  life  years  (DALYs)  lost  due  to  death  and  disability.    Project 
benefits  have  been  estimated  in  terms  of  reduction  of  the  gap  in  DALY  between  the  project 
provinces  and  developed  countries,  multiplied  by  the  2002  per  capita  provincial  minimum 

  16

wages.    Data  derived  from  the  1993  World  Development  Report14  indicates  that  the  gap  in 
DALY between non-Indian and Chinese Asian countries and established market economies was

disease  categories,  using  relatively  recent  (1995)  burden  of  disease  data  on  previous  health 
projects. The value of DALY saved in each province is the monetary value of the minimum wage 
levels in the province.15  For DHS2, the maximum benefit effect assumes a reduction of the gap

7. 
exist or occurs only sporadically. Malaria is a health problem in forest areas of the outer islands, 
particularly in the eastern provinces, where 50% of the cases are plasmodium falciparum. More 
than 1.5 million clinical cases are reported outside Java annually. Malaria control activities are 
integrated  with  the  general  health  services.  Overall  responsibility  for  implementing  malaria 
control  activities  lies  with  district  governments.  Passive  case  detection,  clinical  diagnosis  and

volunteers in the rural areas. The spread of drug resistance, a lack of resources, and a lack of 
intersector collaboration and trained professional staff are some of the major issues. 
 
8.

on the malaria incidence, Indonesia is divided into two regions, Java and Bali, with 70% of the 
total  Indonesian  population,  where  malaria  is  hypoendemic,  and  the  other  sparsely  populated 
islands where malaria is at much higher levels. More than 3.3 million clinical cases of malaria 
were reported in 1998 by government health centers and hospitals. As only 20% of sick people 
go to the government facilities, an estimated 15 million malaria cases probably occur annually. 
The loss of individual income from malaria is estimated at $56.5 million per year, not including 
the loss from tourism and foregone business investment in malaria endemic areas.

Poor  people  are  unable  to  meet  their  minimum  nutritional  requirements  and  tend  to 
suffer from low educational attainment and insufficient skills. Consequently, they may be able to

3. 
Village  health  posts,  health  centers,  mobile  health  centers,  village  midwives,  and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) generally cater to the needs of the poor. District hospitals 
are obliged by law to provide 25% of services free of costs for the poor who are in possession of 
health  cards  (surat  miskin),  issued  by  the  administration  to  certify  the  poverty  status.  But  in 
many rural areas health service facilities are outside the reach of the poor and are often of low 
quality. Access remains an issue for poor people and their health expenditures consist of out-of-
pocket payments.

Economic Analysis 

1. 

Economic Rationale 

 
1. 
The  Second  Decentralized  Health  Services  Project  (DHS2)  focuses  on  improving  the 
role  of  government  in  the  sector  in  a  decentralized  context.  Decentralization  offers  new 
opportunities  to  strengthen  health  and  family  planning  services  in  the  regions  through  locally 
adapted  reforms  giving  health  services  providers  more  appropriate 
incentives,  skills, 
supervision, material support, and discretionary authority needed to offer high quality services, 
and providing clients with information, financial means, and bargaining power required to elicit 
appropriate responses. Investments are needed to help the regions and the central Government 
plan, implement, manage, monitor, and evaluate a range of programs and activities. DHS2 will 
strengthen capacity at district, provincial, and national levels for the delivery of health services.  
It will include planning and management to ensure universal access to good quality health and 
family planning services, and to improve quality, cost efficiency, and sustainability of health and 
family planning services in the DHS2 area. The initial advocacy, training, and technical support 
will build up commitment and capacity of regional governments. The leading role of the public 
health  sector  in  decentralization  will  require  strong  support  and  participation  from  a  variety  of 
stakeholders.  The  DHS2  will  also  address  the  increasingly important  role  of  the  private  health 
sector, the professional associations, and the community in the organization and governance of 
the health system. The primary focus of the DHS2 will be poor and vulnerable groups, and the 
underserved.  DHS2’s support to primary health care (PHC) will play a key role in the decrease 
of maternal and infant mortality, and general morbidity. 
 

2.

more cost-efficient health service delivery systems. The DHS2 increases the economic benefits 
of  decentralization  at  the  provincial  and  district  levels  through  capacity  building,  physical 
investment, and reforms. While there may be savings in the health reforms, such savings will be 
directed  to  increasing  subsidies  to  the  poor.  Health  promotion  activities  will  also  be  targeted 
towards women and the poor to increase health status.
